text: Interesting that you used to want to become an artist. Me too! I studied Art at A-Level and still looove going to art museums and exhibitions.

In the tech industry a lot of jobs are based in Shoreditch/East London (in "Silicon Roundabout" they call it - a play on Silicon Valley in the USA)..luckily lots of artists and creative types live and work there too so you could get exposed to that!
What kind of art do you make? Would love to see some!

No worries about NCS. I've heard it is great for building skills / teamwork etc, but it's not the only way to get the experience. What was it that you liked about NCS? Then I have have a think about other ways to get that experience

We can certainl think about work experience too. Would be great to know what stage you are at e.g. have you made a CV already, have you applied and where, do you have a cover letter/email etc....because I'd be happy to build these with you if you have started one
We do have some things in common :grin:
I do like doing a mixture of art styles in one piece but I do love abstract and landscape I don't mind portraits
Thinking back now, I used to like quite dark and depressing art work and abstracts. Not really portraits so much!

Well the fact that it was a group work experience. I am not so good with socialising, I do get nervous and fail to express my emotions or ideas sometimes. I really really do want to overcome this problem. But I still love doing this on my own
I haven't made a CV yet.  And I'm not sure what a cover letter is

Oh absolutely. Everybody gets nervous about socialising with others at some point. Even to this day I get nervous or prefer time on my own to re-energize. The best thing I found was at university where they forced us to present to a room of people all the time and by the time you have done it 2-3 times you are much more comfortable!

OK so what I'm hearing might be useful for us to work on together could be:
>1) Find group opportunities to build people / networking skills and improve confidence
>2) Build a CV together to help you get work experience
>3) Draft a Cover Letter or Cover Email to send off to companies asking for work experience

Is there anything else you can think of? (We can always add to this list as we go!)

A cover letter is simply a letter (or email) you would send to an employer alongside your CV. It typically details why you want to work for them, what role you want to apply for, why you are well-suited to the job, etc. It can be quite old fashioned as most employers now ask you to apply online, but there are certainly still a good amount of employers that still ask for one of these cover letters!
